bibl.title: John Matthews v. Henry M. White. correspondents
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

org.orgName: District Court of the United States for the Western District of Washington

body.p: To Honorable The Secretary of State, Washington D.C.

Referring to your letter of May 19, 1921, No. Co- 150.616/251, regarding the cause of detention by this Department of one John Matthews, alleged to be Russian subject, you are advised that this man was arrested and ordered deported by the Department for the reason that he has been sentenced, subsequent to the passage og the Immigration Act of February 5, 1917, to imprisonment for a yerm of one year or more because of conviction in this country of a crime involving moral turpitude committed within five years after his entry into the United States, and that he was likely to become a public charge at the time of his entry. The alien states that he came form the State of Chortkoof, town of Noshkofsky, which is now in Ukrainia.
Respectfully, Theodore G. Risley Acting Secretary

The Secretary of state presents his compliments to the the Honorable the Secretary of Labor, and has the honor to enclose a copy of a despatch, dated May 4, 1921, from the American Consul at Fernie, British Columbia, in regard to one John Matthews, said to be a Russian subject at present held for deportation at Seattle.
The Secretary of State will be glad to be advised of the reason for this man's detention in order that the Consul may be duly informed.
THE HONORABLE. THE SECRETARY OF STATE: WASHINGTON

I have the honor to inform you that the Honorable Thomas, Uphill, Member to the Provincial Perliament from this district, requests information as to one John Matthews, now detained by the immigration authorities at Seattle. The said Matthews, who is a Russian and whose brother resides at this point, is stated to have served one year in the federal prison.
Information is desired as to whether there is any possibility of his being released, and if not, then where and when he will be deported.
I have the honor to be, Sir, Your obidient Servant,
